Polling station number 11 near the Tutuchek Outdoor Market is in a working class part of town, where people arrive to vote on the backs of motorcycles and bicycles, not in BMWs, and where almost all the people interviewed said they were voting for Thaksin's Thai Rak Thai Party once again.
Kundua Buntang(ph) is 31 and a local vendor.
(Thai spoken)
Thaksin and his party have done a lot for ordinary people, he says.
Before, people like me couldn't afford to take our families to the doctor when they were sick.
With Thaksin's health plan, we can go to the doctor for 30 baht or about $0.75.
Thaksin, the vendor says, has also helped people start small businesses with his village loan program.
Many coming out of this polling station said much the same thing and this in the capital Bangkok.
In the rural areas, where most Thais live, support for Thaksin is even stronger.
Ms. KUMSUNA CHARUMSUK(ph) (Thai Dressmaker): (Thai spoken)
A lonely dissenting voice at this polling station came from Kumsuna Charumsuk, a 43-year-old dressmaker.
She wants Thaksin out.
She thinks he's corrupt.
But she also says that if Thaksin wins today, then the demonstrations against him should end.
Her argument is a persuasive one and one likely to be welcomed by the embattled prime minister; but it is also one that is not likely to be heeded by the opposition, even if Thaksin does win big.
Michael Sullivan, NPR News, Bangkok.
